Alex Jacobson wrote:

> > The wording in HTTP is "subordinate resource". Wh=
y can't a message
> > resource be "subordinate" to an index resource?
>
> N=
othing about an index implies subordination of indexed resources. You
can
>=
 PUT a message somewhere else and then updating the index. You can add
an
>=
 entry to the index for a URL that does not currently resolve. In
contrast,=

> the only way to add a message to a container is... to add a message to
a=

> container, making the message subordinate to the container. Indexes
don'=
t
> imply subordination. Containership does.

Okay, you're using "container=
" as distinct from, say, "collection" in
WebDAV.

> > That's how directorie=
s work, right?  If I GET a directory, I expect
a
> > hyperlinked list of it=
s contents, not all the contents together in
an
> > archive.
>
> Since HTTP=
 URLs are hierarchical, an enumeration of all subordinate
URLs
> is suffici=
ent to communicate "whatever information" the directory URI
> designates.
>=

> Notably, because indexes don't themselves imply subordination of
indexed=

> resources, you can't take an index to imply that you add a file to a
> d=
irectory by POSTing to it. To get an entry to appear in the index,
you
> mu=
st put a corresponding file in the directory.
>
> So you can view my object=
ion to POSTing to Yannicks message indexes as
> equivalent to objecting to =
POSTing to directory URLs. The semantics
just
> aren't there to do it.

HTT=
P still leaves POST pretty open. As Yannick just quoted, RFC 2616
says,
"Th=
e posted entity is subordinate to that URI in the same way that *a
file
is =
subordinate to a directory containing it*, a news article is
subordinate
to=
 a newsgroup to which it is posted, or a record is subordinate to a
databas=
e" (emphasis mine). But you're right that I wouldn't think of
POSTing
a fil=
e to a directory.

Justin S.
